sentences.sentence: Next Tuesday, the federal government will release its fall fiscal update.

Considering the sorry state of federal finances, it should try a new approach to spending and borrowing: trim both.Don't hold your breath.Although the Trudeau government describes itself(https://www.fraserinstitute.org/blogs/freelands-comments-on-federal-budget-are-head-scratching-and-misleading) as "very fiscally responsible," its track record is unrestrained spending and large budget deficits.

It has overseen the five highest(https://www.fraserinstitute.org/sites/default/files/prime-ministers-and-government-spending-2023.pdf) years (2018 through 2022) of inflation-adjusted per person program spending in Canadian history.
Even excluding COVID-related spending, 2020 and 2021 remain the two highest years of per person spending on record.The Trudeau government has run deficits every year since taking office in 2015.
According to current forecasts, this year's will exceed $40 billion even though COVID is in the rearview mirror.

If it does, federal debt will have increased nearly $900 billion since fiscal year 2014-15, reaching $1.9 trillion for 2023-24.The prime minister and his finance minister, Chrystia Freeland, often downplay the debt their government has accumulated, noting(https://www.budget.canada.ca/2023/pdf/budget-2023-en.pdf) that Canada has the lowest net debt-to-GDP ratio among the G7 countries.

But that statistic is misleading.Net debt, a narrow measure of indebtedness, is calculated(https://www.fraserinstitute.org/article/were-deeper-in-debt-than-ottawa-tells-us) as total (or gross) debt minus all the government's financial assets.
Balancing these assets against the gross debt carries the implicit assumption that they could be sold off to pay the debt, should the need ever arise.
But the calculation includes the assets of the Canada and Quebec Pension Plans (CPP and QPP).
And those assets are spoken for.
They're needed to help finance the pensions of existing and future retirees.

They can't be sold to offset government debt.A better measure of the government's debt is its gross debt, which measures(https://www.fraserinstitute.org/sites/default/files/caution-required-when-comparing-canadas-debt-to-other-countries.pdf) all of its liabilities that require future payment of interest and/or principal.
By this measure we're not nearly so fiscally responsible.
Only eight(https://www.fraserinstitute.org/article/were-deeper-in-debt-than-ottawa-tells-us) of 29 OECD member countries have a higher gross debt than we do.
We are in fact among the most indebted of the world's rich countries.Current levels of spending and borrowing impose real costs on Canadians.
Since 2014-15 federal government debt interest has nearly doubled - reaching a projected $43.9 billion, or 9.6 per cent of total revenues, for 2023-24.

That means roughly one in every 10 dollars Ottawa collects from Canadian taxpayers this year will pay debt interest rather than finance government services or (an unfamiliar concept in Trudeau's Ottawa) tax relief.In light of these fiscal realities, if the government wants to get anywhere near a balanced budget in the foreseeable future, next week's update must take meaningful steps to restrain spending growth.That does seem unlikely.

In a recent report(https://www.pbo-dpb.ca/en/publications/RP-2324-017-S--economic-fiscal-outlook-october-2023--perspectives-economiques-financieres-octobre-2023), the Parliamentary Budget Officer (PBO) estimated that because of spending increases the government will run a deficit of $46.5 billion for 2023-24 - $6.4 billion more than it projected in its March budget(https://www.budget.canada.ca/2023/pdf/budget-2023-en.pdf), just seven months and three weeks ago.

And the update seems likely(https://www.reuters.com/world/americas/it-is-time-canadas-trudeau-trim-sails-spending-2023-11-01/) to add new spending to address housing and affordability, with legislation soon to be tabled for national pharmacare, which the PBO estimates(https://distribution-a617274656661637473.pbo-dpb.ca/c4201c5cc0c9a162ff5f127e98992b64f3547048bf187de65bca2b399f3b9320) will cost $11.2 billion in 2024-25 alone.Dollarizing Argentina could reverse 'pink tide'(https://financialpost.com/opinion/dollarizing-argentina-reverse-pink-tide)Everything is tax-financed, union-produced in progressive heaven(https://financialpost.com/opinion/progressive-heaven-everything-tax-financed-union-produced)Alberta should take a 'random' walk out of the CPP(https://financialpost.com/opinion/alberta-random-walk-out-cpp)Not only does unprecedented spending rack up mountains of debt, Bank of Canada Governor Tiff Macklem says(https://www.theglobeandmail.com/business/article-government-spending-will-start-feeding-into-inflation-next-year/) it is "starting to get in the way of getting inflation back to target" - which means new update spending to address affordability could actually worsen the problem by keeping inflation and interest rates higher than need be, thus eroding Canadians' purchasing power.Ottawa's fiscal situation cries out for a responsible fall update.

But it's hard to bet against predictions that what we'll see is more of the same spending and borrowing that have marked the last eight years.Jake Fuss and Grady Munro are fiscal policy analysts at the Fraser Institute.
